emailColumn.title: elly: Marketing Analytics Startup in the US Market

authorInfo.title: About the Author
authorInfo.description: Seva Ustinov is the founder of Elly, a marketing analytics startup that provides end-to-end marketing analytics solutions combining data from advertising systems, web analytics, and CRM to build comprehensive dashboards and attribution models. Starting as an agency in 2019, the company evolved into a product-focused business and successfully expanded from CIS markets to the United States, focusing on ad-driven lead generating businesses.

keyTakeaways.title: Key Takeaways
keyTakeaways.description: This startup's journey illustrates that successful international expansion requires complete commitment and focus. Key insights include: you cannot effectively pursue international expansion while still managing local operations that demand attention; American markets require radical simplification compared to more technical home markets; customer acquisition costs in the US are significantly higher than expected - plan for 3-5x initial estimates; finding the right advisor or partner who understands the target market is invaluable; and focusing on hyper-specific market segments works better in large markets than broad positioning that works in smaller markets.

I'm excited to dive into your question about our origins and early expansion efforts! The story of how we first ventured beyond our home market is quite interesting ğŸ“Š.

We started in 2019 with a clear vision of eventually going global ğŸŒ, but at that time we simply didn't have the resources or opportunities to launch internationally. We began by fine-tuning our product ğŸ› ï¸, building our team ğŸ‘¥, and developing a better understanding of our audience and value proposition ğŸ¯.

Our product provides end-to-end marketing analytics that combines data from advertising systems ğŸ“±, web analytics ğŸ’», and CRM to build comprehensive dashboards and attribution models ğŸ“ˆ. While we were focused on the home market ğŸ , we remained open to international opportunities when they presented themselves.

Our first international client came in 2021 - a Canadian company ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦ that often works with the CIS engineers. At that time, we didn't even have an English presentation ready and had to create one on the fly! ğŸ˜… While this opportunity came through a chain of recommendations rather than a strategic outreach effort, it provided valuable experience and validation âœ….

Interestingly, this client initially approached us for marketing and growth strategy consulting ğŸ“‹ (as we had started as an agency before developing our analytics product). However, what they really needed was a solution to determine whether their advertising would pay off if they increased their budget tenfold ğŸ’°. This required compiling data from numerous systems - precisely the problem our product was designed to solve ğŸ¯. We were in the right place at the right time with the right solution for their critical strategic question âš¡.

This opportunity didn't arise randomly - it came after years of seizing small chances to work with English-speaking clients ğŸ—£ï¸, even when it wasn't immediately profitable. These experiences, representing just 2% of our total business ğŸ“Š, gave us the confidence to pursue more international work when the time was right â°.

highlight.title: First International Clients Come from Connections
highlight.description: Your first international customer often comes through personal connections or recommendations, not fancy marketing! Even small experiences working with international clients (just 2% of business) can give you confidence and skills for bigger opportunities later.

emails.subject: Evolution of Our International Strategy ğŸ”„
emails.body:
Your inquiry about our early international strategy touches on a fascinating evolution in our thinking ğŸ§ . Let me walk you through how our approach developed over time.

This approach works well for service businesses close to consulting ğŸ’¼, which is why most agencies remain local - they build specific networks in specific locations with years of experience and recommendations ğŸ¤. This model functions similarly across CIS, Australia ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡º, the United States ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸, and elsewhere.

A turning point came when I joined a small forum group of eight founders planning to take local businesses international ğŸ‘¥. For nine months, we met biweekly to discuss plans, progress, and challenges ğŸ“…. The most significant conclusion from this experience was that international expansion would not succeed until we either sold the CIS part of the business or completely stepped away from its operations ğŸš«.

As long as local business demanded our attention - dealing with sales issues ğŸ“, metrics ğŸ“Š, and team management ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ - no international team would work effectively. This realization led us to make a serious commitment to internationalization ğŸŒ, and we hired our first dedicated international team member ğŸ‘”.

By late 2021, I had already built a successful, dividend-paying service business at home ğŸ’° that had completed its transformation to self-governance. It required minimal time and effort from me â°, creating an opportunity to pursue my goal of building a product software venture business for the international market ğŸš€.

While continuing to grow in the home market was certainly possible ğŸ“ˆ, it wasn't as appealing. I had observed that despite several years of growth in all metrics ğŸ“Š, the dollar-adjusted, inflation-adjusted income remained virtually unchanged ğŸ’µ due to periodic internal and external disruptions. Building something global from our local business seemed like the next logical and more interesting step in my development as an entrepreneur ğŸ¯.

highlight.title: You Can't Do Both Local and International Well
highlight.description: A big lesson: you can't successfully expand internationally while still running a demanding local business! You need to either sell your local business or make it run itself, so you can focus 100% on international expansion without distractions.

emails.subject: Resource Allocation and Initial Approach ğŸ’°
emails.body:
I've been reflecting on your thoughtful question about our decision to launch at home before targeting international markets ğŸ¤”. It's a point many entrepreneurs wrestle with, so let me share our reasoning.

The decision to start at home was primarily about resources ğŸ’°. When I became the leader, our agency was still undergoing transformation and wasn't particularly profitable ğŸ“‰. We were facing a crisis with numerous simultaneous changes âš ï¸. At that time, I had no experience raising external funding ğŸ’¸, and it seemed illogical to make all our plans dependent on successfully doing something I'd never done before ğŸš«.

I was also aware of a common trap many entrepreneurs fall into - starting something at the home market that works well ğŸ“ˆ, then struggling to start from scratch elsewhere ğŸ”„. However, I know myself well enough to recognize that I don't fall into such traps ğŸ’ª. The things I want to accomplish eventually happen, even if they take time â°.

Our approach was deliberately measured ğŸ“. We began by selling our analytics service to five projects 5ï¸âƒ£, and then allocated a dedicated team ğŸ‘¥. The agency could still handle simpler analytics work ğŸ“Š, while we focused the new team on building a more technological product ğŸ› ï¸. This approach operated at a small loss for the first few years ğŸ“‰, but it wasn't as drastic as typical venture projects that swing between breaking even and burning significant capital each quarter ğŸ’¸.

The alternative would have been to delay for 2-3 years and start completely fresh â°, but that didn't make sense. When you start moving in a direction, momentum builds ğŸš€ - you begin thinking about it, selling something related, conducting research ğŸ“š, forming a team ğŸ‘¥, and then realizing you need more developers and specialized skills ğŸ’». Each step revealed new insights about architecture and customization needs that informed our development ğŸ’¡.

For our international push ğŸŒ, we initially hired a generalist marketer ğŸ“± and soon after began testing external outreach agencies ğŸ“§. The marketer's role was focused on content and project management ğŸ“‹ - building the website ğŸ’», creating presentations and case studies ğŸ“Š, generating messaging hypotheses ğŸ’­, and meticulously collecting analytics on our outreach efforts ğŸ“ˆ. I needed this support because my calendar was already filled with internal team meetings ğŸ‘¥, networking ğŸ¤, and other calls â˜ï¸, leaving me with only about 10 hours per week for non-urgent tasks â°.

highlight.title: Start Where You Have Resources, Build Momentum
highlight.description: Sometimes you have to start where you can afford to, not where you want to! Building momentum at home first can teach you valuable lessons and give you resources to expand internationally later. Just don't get too comfortable in your home market!

emails.subject: Testing International Channels and Finding Our Approach ğŸ§ª
emails.body:
The strategies we used to test international channels is truly a fascinating topic! I'm glad you brought it up, as it was a critical phase in our global journey ğŸŒ.

We began our serious international push on April 1, 2022 ğŸ“…, after setting up the legal structure and banking relationships ğŸ¦. My business partner and I agreed to bet on global expansion immediately rather than postponing it ğŸš€. Interestingly, at this time, all sales at home came to a halt as businesses were focused on more immediate concerns following global events ğŸŒ.

We made a strategic decision not to hire anyone for our CIS business until we sold it ğŸš«, as growth there would distract us from our global ambitions. Instead, we used home operation for product development ğŸ› ï¸, process refinement ğŸ”§, and facilitating a smooth transition to global markets ğŸŒ.

Initially, we weren't certain which specific country to target ğŸ¤”. I spent considerable time networking with founders on similar internationalization journeys or those who had succeeded years earlier ğŸ‘¥. I needed to understand how marketing and management differed globally compared to home ones ğŸ“Š. The surprising discovery was that there are very few differences - performance marketing functions essentially the same way worldwide ğŸ“ˆ!

We ran parallel tracks: one for research and networking ğŸ” (including travel to Armenia ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡², Turkey ğŸ‡¹ğŸ‡·, Latin America ğŸŒ, and Dubai ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª to meet people), and another for testing outreach channels ğŸ“§. Our outreach testing focused primarily on the US market ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ from the beginning, as it seemed the most potentially interesting, though we hadn't fully committed to it yet.

By the end of 2022, we had decided to focus exclusively on the US ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸. In January 2023, I visited the US for the first time for several months âœˆï¸, solidifying our commitment to this market.

For our outreach testing ğŸ“¨, we chose cold email over LinkedIn initially, not because one is inherently better than the other, but because we found agencies with strong email expertise ğŸ’¯. When you're testing multiple variables (country ğŸŒ, vertical ğŸ¢, client size ğŸ“, problem specifics ğŸ¯, messaging ğŸ’¬, offer ğŸ’°, communication chain ğŸ”—), it's best to limit the channels you're testing simultaneously. If email works âœ…, LinkedIn will likely work too, and vice versa.

The task was to find a combination that would generate our first sales ğŸ’° - a sign that we could refine this approach into a scalable channel with a viable economic model ğŸ“Š. We focused only on potentially scalable experiments and spread our tests across diverse variables ğŸ¯, like playing battleship - trying different points on the board rather than clustering around one area ğŸ®.

highlight.title: Test One Channel Well, Then Expand
highlight.description: When testing international markets, don't try to test everything at once! Pick one channel (like email) and get really good at it first. If email works, LinkedIn probably will too. Focus on finding one thing that works before trying ten different approaches.

emails.subject: Finding the Right People and Partners ğŸ¤
emails.body:
To address your question about talent acquisition for international expansion - this was indeed one of our most crucial challenges! ğŸ¯

Our approach to outreach agencies was based on recommendations and favorable terms ğŸ’°. The first agency we worked with specialized in cold calling â˜ï¸ and only charged for scheduled meetings, making it a low-risk test given our limited resources. The second agency focused on email outreach ğŸ“§; while they operated on a subscription model, I was impressed with the founder's personal involvement, advice, and presentations during our discussions in the Earth Founders community ğŸ‘¥.

Working with these specialized agencies provided valuable insights even when they didn't deliver the expected results ğŸ“Š. The cold calling agency generated some meetings but had a high no-show rate ğŸš«, and those who did attend often seemed confused about the purpose ğŸ¤”. The email outreach agency helped us test different segments by vertical and region ğŸŒ, which improved our understanding of our most promising markets, even though we didn't secure any sales directly through them ğŸ“ˆ.

This approach of starting with agencies rather than hiring in-house specialists is one I recommend ğŸ’¡. When you lack expertise in a particular area, specialized agencies offer teams with processes ğŸ“‹, standards â­, templates ğŸ“„, and experience ğŸ†. Together, you can determine what works for your specific business. If it succeeds âœ…, you can continue the partnership; if not, you've gained valuable experience about the channel and understand what to look for if you decide to hire someone internally ğŸ‘”.

A significant breakthrough came when we found an excellent advisor from the American market ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ who had previously been our partner. When he changed jobs and had some downtime â°, we established an advisory relationship ğŸ¤. He provided crucial insights about the American market, sales processes, and costs - dispelling my illusion that clients could be acquired for $5,000-6,000 total cost per deal ğŸ’¸. He showed me that American salespeople earn considerably more than I had estimated ğŸ’°, and that we needed to multiply our budget figures by at least three, with industry benchmarks suggesting a factor of five 5ï¸âƒ£!

This advisor helped us create a model for hiring our first salesperson ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ and set up email outreach on our domains ğŸ“§. From the very first campaign, we secured an interesting lead ğŸ¯. The salesperson conducted an American-style sales pitch ğŸ—£ï¸, passed me the call ğŸ“, and after five days of brief follow-up calls, the prospect became a customer ğŸ‰. This experience provided tremendous confidence and clarity about how the US sales process works ğŸ’ª.

highlight.title: Good Advisors Are Worth Their Weight in Gold
highlight.description: Finding someone who really understands your target market can save you tons of time and money! They showed them that US salespeople cost much more than expected - sometimes 3-5x more than initial estimates. A good advisor helps you avoid expensive mistakes.

emails.subject: Adapting Our Sales Approach for the US Market ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸
emails.body:
The cultural nuances between CIS and American business practices you mentioned are spot-on! Let me share how we navigated these differences and transformed our approach ğŸ”„.

The most significant discovery was the need for radical simplification ğŸ“‰. Americans prefer straightforward explanations and visuals ğŸ‘€. While we initially impressed our home customers with complex dashboards showing all our capabilities ğŸ“Š, these same presentations scared American prospects ğŸ˜°.

We redesigned our demo to start with simple dashboards featuring graphs and six key figures color-coded green and red ğŸŸ¢ğŸ”´, relegating the more detailed, complex reports to separate sheets that could be explored later if desired ğŸ“‹. We also found technological solutions to eliminate almost all integration tasks that previously required client engineering resources ğŸ› ï¸.

This was crucial because American companies often have six-month engineering backlogs â°, and any product requiring significant technical integration would be immediately rejected ğŸš«. When prospects asked about implementation, we simplified to requiring just one line of code added to their website ğŸ’».

With the help of AI ğŸ¤–, we created an interactive model demonstrating our value in 60 seconds â±ï¸. The model shows three advertising campaigns with their lead generation costs ğŸ’°, then reveals how qualified leads change the cost equation ğŸ“Š, and finally demonstrates how tracking paying customers and their lifetime value completely transforms budget allocation decisions ğŸ¯. This simple, interactive approach makes our value proposition immediately clear âœ¨.

We also discovered that the average level of technical sophistication among marketers varies significantly between regions ğŸŒ. While Moscow has many technically proficient marketers from top universities like Bauman and Phystech ğŸ“, the average American marketer outside major tech companies has less mathematical background and fewer engineering skills ğŸ“. They excel at storytelling ğŸ“š and applying standard playbooks ğŸ“– but often lack the systematic approach found in more technical environments.

This isn't surprising given America's population of 340 million spread across relatively evenly developed regions ğŸ—ºï¸. The truly technical marketers in the US typically earn $500,000+ annually working in corporations and top startups ğŸ’¸ - not our target market.

Another key learning was the importance of hyper-segmentation ğŸ¯ - a distinctly American characteristic that puzzles professionals from other countries. In the US, you find highly specialized solutions for incredibly narrow segments - CRMs specifically for dental clinics ğŸ¦·, for example. While in CIS, we could offer end-to-end analytics services to a broad customer base, in America this approach doesn't work ğŸš«. The market is so large that even hyper-specific segments contain thousands of potential customers with appropriate budgets ğŸ’°.

Our most successful approach has been focusing on "ad-driven lead generating businesses" ğŸ“± like medical clinics ğŸ¥, property developers ğŸ—ï¸, automotive dealers ğŸš—, and certain service providers. These businesses understand the problem of tracking not just ad-generated leads but also real customers and their lifetime value ğŸ“ˆ.

highlight.title: Simplify Everything for American Markets
highlight.description: Americans like things simple and clear! Complex dashboards that impress technical customers at home might scare American customers away. Focus on showing your main value in 60 seconds or less, and make it super easy to understand and implement.

emails.subject: Our Journey to Market Fit and Key Lessons ğŸ¯
emails.body:
Your question about our path to achieving product-market fit comes at the perfect time - we've recently reached some significant milestones after navigating several challenging detours! ğŸš€

One of our costliest mistakes was spending significant time and resources pursuing the e-commerce vertical (Ecom) ğŸ›’. We were encouraged by receiving leads and even making a few sales in this segment ğŸ“ˆ, but we failed to recognize that established competitors like Triple Whale ğŸ‹ and Northbeam had already captured the market.

These competitors had several advantages: they integrated directly with Shopify ğŸ›ï¸ (used by 80% of online stores), offered more affordable pricing ğŸ’° (3-4 times cheaper than our solution), and had spent years building brand recognition by sponsoring conferences ğŸ¤ and accumulating case studies ğŸ“Š. Despite our greater customization capabilities ğŸ› ï¸, the value proposition wasn't compelling enough to overcome these barriers.

We lost considerable time focusing on this segment because the initial positive signals (leads, interest, and some sales) ğŸ“Š masked the ultimately low conversion rate to closed deals ğŸ“‰. However, this experience helped us identify our true target market - what we call "ad-driven lead generating businesses" ğŸ¯ like clinics ğŸ¥, developers ğŸ—ï¸, automotive dealers ğŸš—, and service businesses.

These companies understand the need to track not just lead acquisition costs ğŸ’¸ but also conversion to actual customers and lifetime value ğŸ“ˆ. Most importantly, when we asked about existing solutions to this problem â“, virtually no one could name any serious competitors. The few services operating in this segment were small ğŸ“‰, not growing rapidly, and posed no significant competitive threat ğŸš«.

After restructuring our marketing for this segment in early 2024 ğŸ“…, we began securing deals consistently - about three new clients monthly ğŸ“Š. This steady growth attracted investor interest ğŸ’°, and we recently completed our seed funding round ğŸ‰.

If I could do things differently ğŸ”„, I would have attracted more investment earlier and assembled a stronger team from the start ğŸ‘¥. With limited resources, I tried to handle too much myself with minimal support ğŸ˜…, but having several senior people from the beginning accelerates testing and learning exponentially ğŸ“ˆ. I would also have immediately focused on making everything as simple and straightforward as possible for the American market ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸, where clarity and directness are highly valued ğŸ’¡.

My inbox changed dramatically after moving to the US market ğŸ“§ - suddenly filled with interesting, well-crafted offers and advertisements ğŸ“±. Visit a product website once, and you'll see polished messaging from all its competitors across multiple channels in the following days ğŸ“º. While this intensifies the challenge of breaking into the market (requiring you to be notably better than competitors) ğŸ†, it also creates opportunities to excel in carefully chosen niches ğŸ¯.

Our next major milestone will be optimizing our cost structure to offer the full integration cycle for free ğŸ†“, allowing clients to experience the value before making a final decision ğŸ’­. This change should accelerate our growth from three times annually to potentially ten times ğŸš€.

highlight.title: Don't Chase Competitive Markets, Find Your Niche
highlight.description: Sometimes early success in a market segment can trick you into thinking it's the right path! They wasted time on e-commerce because competitors were already dominating it. Better to find a market where customers can't name any competitors - that's your sweet spot!
